* `Param()`/`SetParam()`.
* Specific accessors. E.g.: `Temperature()`/`SetTemperature()`.

Is there any reason for keeping both options public?

It seems that there are two ways of accessing to the atmosphere parameters:

  • Param()/SetParam().
  • Specific accessors. E.g.: Temperature()/SetTemperature().

Is there any reason for keeping both options public?

content.raw: We internally discussed how to use opaque pointers with inheritance recently. We agreed to make `dataPtr` always private. In your case  `AdiabaticAtmospherePrivate` shouldn't inherit from any other class. If you need to access the members of the base class in your derived classes you can use the function accessors.

content.raw:
There was a typo in the computation of adiabaticPower, it has now been fixed. A reference has been added: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Density_of_air#Altitude
Pressure and air density calculations are exactly like described on this page.
content.html: There was a typo in the computation of adiabaticPower, it has now been fixed. A reference has been added: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Density_of_air#Altitude Pressure and air density calculations are exactly like described on this page.

content.raw:
In case you want to verify the equation for the computation of air density, below are the steps that brings you from `rho = pM/RT` to the equation we use in the code by replacing pressure `p` and temperature `T` by their `p(z)` and `T(z)` forms:

```
#!c++

rho(z) = M/(RT(z)) * (p0(1+a.z/T0)^Mg/aR)
rho(z) = M/(R.T0)* (1+a.z/T0) *(p0(1+a.z/T0)^Mg/aR)
rho(z) = p0M/(R.T0)*(1+a.z/T0)^Mg/aR-1
rho(z) = rho0(1+a.z/T0)^Mg/aR-1 
```
content.html:
In case you want to verify the equation for the computation of air density, below are the steps that brings you from rho = pM/RT to the equation we use in the code by replacing pressure p and temperature T by their p(z) and T(z) forms:

rho(z) = M/(RT(z)) * (p0(1+a.z/T0)^Mg/aR)
rho(z) = M/(R.T0)* (1+a.z/T0) *(p0(1+a.z/T0)^Mg/aR)
rho(z) = p0M/(R.T0)*(1+a.z/T0)^Mg/aR-1
rho(z) = rho0(1+a.z/T0)^Mg/aR-1

content.html: Awesome, thanks for the link and the equations, it all looks good to me except for a - sign.

content.raw: Could you expand on the assumptions here? I assume the ideal gas law is being used as well? Perhaps provide a reference?
content.html: Could you expand on the assumptions here? I assume the ideal gas law is being used as well? Perhaps provide a reference?

content.raw:
For the `AdiabaticAtmosphere`, I think there is a possibility of an inconsistent state. According to wikipedia, the [ideal gas law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideal_gas_law#Molar_form) has the following form: `P = rho * (R / M) * T` where

* `P` is pressure
* `rho` is density
* `R` is the universal gas constant
* `M` is the molar mass of the gas in question
* `T` is temperature

`R` and `M` are specified as static constants in `AdiabaticAtmosphere`, while the values of `P`, `rho`, and `T` at sea-level are independently stored in `AtmospherePrivate` and provide independent Set functions. The latter three variables could be set independently to values that would violate the ideal gas law.

For constant values of `R` and `M`, I think the proper way to set the state is with functions that take pairs of variables (`P,T`, `P,rho`, `rho,T`) and use the ideal gas law to compute the value of the third variable. Then the three state variables should satisfy the ideal gas law. Does that make sense?
content.html:
For the AdiabaticAtmosphere, I think there is a possibility of an inconsistent state. According to wikipedia, the ideal gas law has the following form: P = rho * (R / M) * T where

  • P is pressure
  • rho is density
  • R is the universal gas constant
  • M is the molar mass of the gas in question
  • T is temperature

R and M are specified as static constants in AdiabaticAtmosphere, while the values of P, rho, and T at sea-level are independently stored in AtmospherePrivate and provide independent Set functions. The latter three variables could be set independently to values that would violate the ideal gas law.

For constant values of R and M, I think the proper way to set the state is with functions that take pairs of variables (P,T, P,rho, rho,T) and use the ideal gas law to compute the value of the third variable. Then the three state variables should satisfy the ideal gas law. Does that make sense?

content.raw:
You are right, there should be a mechanism to verify that the ideal gas law is respected. We see two ways to fix this:

* Let the user define two values and compute the third one as you suggest. In this case, the user will have complete control, but at the cost of having to do more verifications when loading the atmosphere model. The big issue is that it would mean that not one value could be set singly. It means that we would have to replace methods like `SetTemperature` with `SetTemperatureAndPressure` and `SetTemperatureAndMassDensity`, or we would have to compute arbitrary values for `P` and `rho` when setting `T`.
* Or we could let the user define only two values. In our case, that would be sufficient. We just need to define `P` and `T` and compute `rho` automatically. The `rho` parameter could still appear in gzclient, but as a read-only parameter.

What do you think?
content.html:
You are right, there should be a mechanism to verify that the ideal gas law is respected. We see two ways to fix this:

  • Let the user define two values and compute the third one as you suggest. In this case, the user will have complete control, but at the cost of having to do more verifications when loading the atmosphere model. The big issue is that it would mean that not one value could be set singly. It means that we would have to replace methods like SetTemperature with SetTemperatureAndPressure and SetTemperatureAndMassDensity, or we would have to compute arbitrary values for P and rho when setting T.
  • Or we could let the user define only two values. In our case, that would be sufficient. We just need to define P and T and compute rho automatically. The rho parameter could still appear in gzclient, but as a read-only parameter.

What do you think?

content.raw: The last commit implements the second solution. In that case, we would also have to remove element `mass_density` from the list of `atmosphere` SDF children. `mass_density` is still sent in the `atmosphere` topic and displayed in gzclient as a read-only field.
content.html: The last commit implements the second solution. In that case, we would also have to remove element mass_density from the list of atmosphere SDF children. mass_density is still sent in the atmosphere topic and displayed in gzclient as a read-only field.

content.raw: I had a few comments that were not addressed, specifically about providing a reference for the AdiabaticAtmosphere. There are some links to different wikipedia pages in various places, but I would like to see something in the header file that describes the assumptions of the model (ie. ideal gas law and ???) and gives a reference to a textbook or something other than wikipedia. Mainly, I don't know how they derived the formula on wikipedia and what assumptions are used.
content.html: I had a few comments that were not addressed, specifically about providing a reference for the AdiabaticAtmosphere. There are some links to different wikipedia pages in various places, but I would like to see something in the header file that describes the assumptions of the model (ie. ideal gas law and ???) and gives a reference to a textbook or something other than wikipedia. Mainly, I don't know how they derived the formula on wikipedia and what assumptions are used.

content.raw: You can find the same equations in the introduction of the [Manual of the ICAO Standard Atmosphere](http://ntrs.nasa.gov/search.jsp?R=19930083952). The adiabatic model assumes that the ideal gas law is followed and that the temperature of the atmosphere decreases with increasing height at a constant rate.
content.html: You can find the same equations in the introduction of the Manual of the ICAO Standard Atmosphere. The adiabatic model assumes that the ideal gas law is followed and that the temperature of the atmosphere decreases with increasing height at a constant rate.
